### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: We can be sure that at least some halogen lamps are well crafted, because halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth. Any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
Question: Which one of the following arguments is most similar in its reasoning to the argument above?
Choices:
  A: We can be confident that the temperature will drop abruptly on at least one day this week, for there is a chance of storms most days this week; whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: We can be positive that there are at least a few disturbing sonnets, given that Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets; everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: We can be sure that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car, because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: We can be positive that at least some minnows are healthy, because many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby, and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: We can be confident that the cornmeal used at Matteo's Trattoria is healthful and organic, since cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals there; whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The argument states that halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth and any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
  A: The argument states that there is a chance of storms most days this week and whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: The argument states that Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets and everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: The argument states that Gianna can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: The argument states that many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: The argument states that cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals at Matteo's Trattoria and whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
Thought: 
  The argument concludes that some halogen lamps are well crafted because halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth and any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
  A: The argument concludes that the temperature will drop abruptly on at least one day this week because there is a chance of storms most days this week and whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: The argument concludes that there are at least a few disturbing sonnets because Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets and everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: The argument concludes that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: The argument concludes that at least some minnows are healthy because many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: The argument concludes that the cornmeal used at Matteo's Trattoria is healthful and organic since cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals there and whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
  The argument in option C is most similar in its reasoning to the argument above.
Criticism: 
  The argument in option C is not exactly similar to the argument above. 
  The argument above concludes that some halogen lamps are well crafted because halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth and any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
  The argument in option C concludes that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  The argument in option E is more similar in its reasoning to the argument above.

  Therefore, the answer is C: We can be sure that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car, because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Harrold Foods is attempting to dominate the soft-drink market by promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign. But survey results show that, in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers, "Hero" already dominates the market. Since any product with more than 50 percent of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market, Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
Question: The argument commits which one of the following errors in reasoning?
Choices:
  A: failing to exclude the possibility that what appears to be the result of a given market condition may in fact be the cause of that condition
  B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result
  C: treating the failure to establish that a certain claim is false as equivalent to a demonstration that that claim is true
  D: taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true
  E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Harrold Foods is promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign to dominate the soft-drink market.
  Survey results show that 72% of all consumers believe that "Hero" already dominates the market.
  Any product with more than 50% of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market.
Thought: 
  The argument claims that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
  The argument uses the survey results to support the claim that "Hero" dominates the market.
  However, the survey results only show the opinion of consumers, not the actual sales data.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.
  The survey results are not sufficient to guarantee that "Hero" dominates the market.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  The argument is about Harrold Foods attempting to dominate the soft-drink market by promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign.
  The argument states that survey results show that, in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers, "Hero" already dominates the market.
  The argument concludes that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
Thought:
  The argument claims that Harrold Foods dominates the market now because "Hero" already dominates the market in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers.
  However, the argument does not consider the possibility that the survey results may not be accurate or may not reflect the actual market conditions.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true.
  The answer is D: taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true.
Criticism:
  The argument does not mistake a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result (B).
  The argument does not treat the failure to establish that a certain claim is false as equivalent to a demonstration that that claim is true (C).
  The argument does not describe survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well (E).
Action: Answer("D")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  Harrold Foods is promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign to dominate the soft-drink market.
  Survey results show that 72% of all consumers believe that "Hero" already dominates the market.
  Any product with more than 50% of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market.
Thought: 
  The argument claims that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
  The argument uses the survey results to support the claim that "Hero" already dominates the market.
  However, the argument fails to consider that the survey results may not accurately reflect the current market conditions.
  The argument assumes that the market conditions will remain the same in the future, but this may not be the case.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 3:
Knowledge: 
  The argument is about Harrold Foods and its attempt to dominate the soft-drink market.
  The argument claims that Harrold Foods dominates the market because "Hero" already dominates the market in the opinion of 72% of all consumers.
  The argument concludes that Harrold Foods need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to dominate the market.
Thought: 
  The argument assumes that the opinion of 72% of all consumers is an accurate representation of the market.
  The argument does not provide any evidence to support the claim that Harrold Foods' advertising campaign will not be matched by competitors.
  The argument assumes that the market will remain static and that Harrold Foods will maintain its current market share.
  The argument commits the error of mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.
  Therefore, the answer is B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.
Criticism: 
  Your answer is correct.
  The argument assumes that the market will remain static and that Harrold Foods will maintain its current market share, which is not necessarily true.
  The argument also assumes that the opinion of 72% of all consumers is an accurate representation of the market, which may not be true.

Response 6:
Knowledge:
  The argument is about Harrold Foods attempting to dominate the soft-drink market by promoting its most popular carbonated drink product, "Hero," with a costly new advertising campaign.
  The argument mentions that survey results show that 72% of all consumers think that "Hero" already dominates the market.
  The argument concludes that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and only needs to maintain its current market share to continue to do so.
Thought:
  The argument is using the fact that 72% of consumers believe that "Hero" dominates the market as evidence that Harrold Foods actually dominates the market.
  However, the argument does not consider the possibility that the survey results are not accurate or that the survey respondents may not be representative of the entire market.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true.
  The answer is D: taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true.
Criticism:
  The argument does not mistake a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result (B).
  The argument does not treat the failure to establish that a certain claim is false as equivalent to a demonstration that that claim is true (C).

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Science journalist: Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars. They are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres. Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete. Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed. A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the science journalist's statements?
Choices:
  A: Any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is a star with less mass than the Sun.
  B: Any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.
  C: No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
  D: No celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
  E: No celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
- Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars.
- Brown dwarfs are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres.
- Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete.
- Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed.
- A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.

Thought:
- The journalist states that brown dwarfs are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres.
- The journalist explains that stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed.
- The journalist explains that brown dwarfs do not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so their lithium cannot be consumed.
- Therefore, a celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere must have a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements, and any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is not a star with less mass than the Sun.

Evaluation:
- Choice A is incorrect because the journalist only stated that stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium, but did not say that any celestial object without lithium is a star with less mass than the Sun.
- Choice B is the most strongly supported by the journalist's statements because the journalist explained that stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete, and that a brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.
- Choice C is incorrect because the journalist did not say that no celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
- Choice D is incorrect because the journalist did not say that no celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
- Choice E is incorrect because the journalist did not say that no celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A computer game publisher has recently released its latest adventure game. The game's inventive puzzles and compelling plot induce even casual players to become preoccupied with completing it. The game can be purchased from retail outlets or rented for two-day intervals. The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game, saving them a significant portion of the purchase price. Since the rate of sales now meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations, the publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to justify the publisher's prediction?
Choices:
  A: The game can be purchased directly from the publisher as well as from retailers.
  B: It takes several weeks for most players to complete the game.
  C: The publisher's games are among the most popular computer games on the market.
  D: Most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward.
  E: Some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The game publisher has released a new adventure game that can be purchased or rented.
  The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game.
  The rate of sales meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations.
Thought: 
  The publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
  To justify this prediction, we need to find an option that supports the idea that people are likely to buy the game after renting it.
  A: This option does not provide any information about whether people are likely to buy the game after renting it.
  B: This option does not provide any information about whether people are likely to buy the game after renting it.
  C: This option does not provide any information about whether people are likely to buy the game after renting it.
  D: This option suggests that people are not likely to play the game extensively after completing it, which may mean they are more likely to buy it after renting it.
  E: This option does not provide any information about whether people are likely to buy the game after renting it.
  Therefore, the best answer is D: Most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("D")

  E: This option suggests that some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend, which may or may not be relevant to the prediction.
  Option A, C, D, and E do not provide any information that justifies the publisher's prediction.
  Option B suggests that players take a long time to complete the game, which means they may need to rent it multiple times before completing it. This increases the likelihood that they will purchase the game instead of renting it repeatedly.
  Therefore, Option B most helps to justify the publisher's prediction.
Action: Answer("B")

Context: Had the party's economic theories been sound and had it succeeded in implementing its program, the inflation rate would have lessened considerably. But because the inflation rate actually increased, the party's economic theories were fur off the mark.
Question: The flawed reasoning in which one oflbe following arguments most closely resembles the flawed reasoning in the argument above?
Choices:
  A: If the people who inhabited the valley for so long had been invaded, or iflbere had been a dramatic climatic change, there would have been chaoges in the valley's architecture. But architecture in the valley remained the same throughout their stay. Thus, the valley people must not have been invaded at any time during their stay.
  B: Many people fear that iflbe opposition party wins the election and keeps its promise to cut wages dramatically, workers in key industries will strike. But because the workers have promised not to strike, these workers must think the party will not keep its promise of a dramatic wage cut.
  C: If the company had succeeded in selling its subsidiaries and used the cash to purchase the new patent, its stock price would have doubled in the last two years. But the price oflbe stock did not increase in that time. Thus, the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  D: City residents were expected to show a great deal of support for the rebels iflbe battle was won and the jailed rebel leaders freed. Residents have shown a great deal of support or the rebels for the last three days. Therefore, the rebels must have won the battle.
  E: Iflbe television station's new wealber forecasting equipment had been worth the investment, the accuracy of its forecasts would have risen, along wilb its ratings. But the station's ratings actually decreased. Thus, the new equipment is no improvement on the old.

  B: The argument states that many people fear that if the opposition party wins the election and keeps its promise to cut wages dramatically, workers in key industries will strike. But the price of the stock did not increase in that time, so the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  Both arguments make a conditional statement that if one thing happened, then another thing would have happened. However, because the expected outcome did not occur, the argument concludes that the initial condition did not occur either.
  Therefore, the flawed reasoning in the argument above most closely resembles the flawed reasoning in option C.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 61 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Government official: Residents who are foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries. This is wise, since cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens, and no one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform. Moreover, a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable. So, ____.
Question: Which one of the following most logically completes the government official's statement?
Choices:
  A: foreign citizens who serve as public servants should be granted citizenship in the country they serve
  B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries
  C: only former cabinet undersecretaries should be appointed as cabinet secretaries
  D: foreign citizens should be eligible to serve as cabinet secretaries
  E: cabinet undersecretaries should not be expected to stand in for cabinet secretaries
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  Cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  No one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
Thought: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  The official also believes that a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  Therefore, it would be inconsistent to allow foreign citizens to serve as cabinet undersecretaries, since they may need to perform duties that should only be performed by citizens.
  The most logical completion of the government official's statement is B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  Cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  No one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
Thought: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  The official believes that cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  Therefore, it would be logical to conclude that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries, since they may be called upon to perform duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  The answer is B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
Criticism: 
  You are correct that the government official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  However, the official did not state that cabinet undersecretaries should not be foreign citizens.
  So, the answer could also be D: foreign citizens should be eligible to serve as cabinet secretaries.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Figorian Wildlife Commission: The development of wetlands in industrialized nations for residential and commercial uses has endangered many species. To protect wildlife we must regulate such development in Figoria: future wetland development must be offset by the construction of replacement wetland habitats. Thus, development would cause no net reduction of wetlands and pose no threat to the species that inhabit them. Figorian Development Commission: Other nations have flagrantly developed wetlands at the expense of wildlife. We have conserved. Since Figorian wetland development might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, we should allow development. We have as much right to govern our own resources as countries that have already put their natural resources to commercial use.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if accepted, would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position against the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position?
Choices:
  A: National resources should be regulated by international agreement when wildlife is endangered.
  B: The right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations.
  C: Only when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found should regulation be implemented to prevent further damage.
  D: Environment regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment.
  E: It is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The Figorian Wildlife Commission believes that wetland development should be regulated in order to protect wildlife.
  The Figorian Development Commission believes that wetland development is necessary for growth and that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources.
Thought: 
  The Figorian Development Commission's position is that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources and that wetland development is necessary for growth.
  Therefore, a principle that supports the idea that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  Choice D states that environmental regulation cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment. This principle supports the idea that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources without being subject to the same regulations as other nations that have already harmed the environment.
  Therefore, choice D would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position against the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
Action: Answer("D")

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 63 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Columnist: Although most people favor the bill and the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, it will not be passed for many years, if at all; nor will any similar bill. Those people who would be adversely affected were it to become law are very influential. This shows that, if this country is a democracy at all, it is not a well-functioning one.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the columnist's reasoning?
Choices:
  A: In a well-functioning democracy, any bill that would benefit most people will be passed into law within a few years if it does not violate anyone's basic human rights.
  B: If a democracy is well functioning, then any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law.
  C: In a well-functioning democracy, a bill that is favored by most people will become law within a few years only if those who oppose it are not very influential.
  D: Any bill passed into law in a well-functioning democracy will be favored by most people and be consistent with individuals' basic human rights.
  E: A bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights.

  The columnist argues that a bill favored by most people and not violating anyone's basic human rights will not be passed into law due to the influence of those who would be adversely affected.

  C: This principle states that a bill that is favored by most people will become law within a few years only if those who oppose it are not very influential, which is consistent with the columnist's argument.
  D: This principle states that any bill passed into law in a well-functioning democracy will be favored by most people and be consistent with individuals' basic human rights, which is not consistent with the columnist's argument.
  E: This principle states that a bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, which is not consistent with the columnist's argument.
Thought: 
  The columnist argues that a bill that is favored by most people and does not violate anyone's basic human rights will not be passed into law because those who would be adversely affected are very influential.
  Principle B states that any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law.
  This principle supports the columnist's argument.
  Therefore, principle B is the most helpful in justifying the columnist's reasoning.
Action: Answer("B")

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Editorial: The premier's economic advisor assures her that with the elimination of wasteful spending the goal of reducing taxes while not significantly decreasing government services can be met. But the premier should not listen to this advisor, who in his youth was convicted of embezzlement. Surely his economic advice is as untrustworthy as he is himself, and so the premier should discard any hope of reducing taxes without a significant decrease in government services.
Question: Which one of the following is a questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument?
Choices:
  A: rejecting a proposal on the grounds that a particular implementation of the proposal is likely to fail
  B: trying to win support for a proposal by playing on people's fears of what could happen otherwise
  C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself
  D: taking lack of evidence for a claim as evidence undermining that claim
  E: presupposing what it sets out to establish
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth. 
  A: This choice is not relevant to the editorial's argument.
  B: This choice is not relevant to the editorial's argument.
  C: The editorial criticizes the economic advisor's character rather than examining the quality of his economic advice.
  D: This choice is not relevant to the editorial's argument.
  E: The editorial presupposes that the economic advisor's advice is untrustworthy and that reducing taxes without a significant decrease in government services is impossible.
Thought: 
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth.
  The editorial criticizes the economic advisor's character rather than examining the quality of his economic advice.
  Therefore, the questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument is criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself.
  The answer is C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself.
Criticism: 
  Your analysis is correct.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 65 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Biologist: Humans have five fingers because we descended from a fish with five phalanges in its fins. Despite our prejudices to the contrary, our configuration of fingers is no more or less useful than several other possible configurations, e.g., six per hand. So, if humans had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins and had six fingers on each hand, then we would be just as content with that configuration.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the biologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Everyone is equally content with our present configuration of fingers.
  B: Humans are never equally content with two things of unequal usefulness.
  C: Humans are always equally content with two things of equal usefulness.
  D: The perceived usefulness of our configuration of fingers is an illusory result of our prejudices.
  E: At least one species of fish had six phalanges in its fins.
Response 0:

- The biologist argues that humans' five-finger configuration is not inherently superior to other possible configurations.
- The biologist suggests that humans would be content with a different configuration if we had evolved from a fish with that configuration.

- Therefore, an answer choice that supports the idea that humans' preference for a five-finger configuration is not based on any inherent superiority would strengthen the biologist's argument.
- Answer choice A does not strengthen the argument because it does not address the issue of whether the five-finger configuration is inherently superior.
- Answer choice B actually weakens the argument by suggesting that humans are not content with things of unequal usefulness, which implies that the five-finger configuration is inherently more useful than other configurations.
- Answer choice C is irrelevant because it does not address the issue of whether the five-finger configuration is inherently superior.
- Answer choice D supports the biologist's argument by suggesting that our perception of the usefulness of the five-finger configuration is based on our prejudices rather than any inherent superiority.
- Answer choice E is irrelevant because it does not address the issue of whether the five-finger configuration is inherently superior.

- The biologist's argument is based on the assumption that humans' preference for a five-finger configuration is not based on any inherent superiority of that configuration.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 66 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Dried parsley should never be used in cooking, for it is far less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley is.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most clearly helps to justify the argument above?
Choices:
  A: Fresh ingredients should be used in cooking whenever possible.
  B: Only the tastiest ingredients should ever be used in cooking.
  C: Ingredients that should never be used in cooking are generally neither tasty nor healthful.
  D: Parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used in cooking.
  E: In cooking, dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument claims that dried parsley should never be used in cooking because it is less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley.
Thought:
  The argument is based on the premise that dried parsley is less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley.
  The principle that would most clearly help to justify this argument is that fresh ingredients should be used in cooking whenever possible.
  Therefore, the answer is A: Fresh ingredients should be used in cooking whenever possible.
Criticism:
  The argument does not claim that only the tastiest ingredients should be used in cooking, so B is not the correct answer.
  The argument also does not claim that ingredients that should never be used in cooking are generally neither tasty nor healthful, so C is not the correct answer.
  The argument is specifically about parsley, so D is not the correct answer.
  The argument is not a general statement about the superiority of fresh ingredients over dried ingredients, so E is not the correct answer.
Action: Answer("A")

  C: This principle states that ingredients that should never be used in cooking are generally neither tasty nor healthful.
  D: This principle states that parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used in cooking.
  E: This principle states that in cooking, dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients.

  Principle A is too broad and does not specifically address the issue of dried parsley.
  Principle B is too extreme and does not take into account other factors such as healthfulness.
  Principle C is too general and does not specifically address the issue of dried parsley.
  Principle D is too extreme and does not take into account other factors such as the practicality of finding tasty and healthful parsley.
  Principle E directly addresses the issue of dried parsley being less tasty and is therefore the most relevant principle to justify the argument.
  Therefore, the answer is E: In cooking, dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients.
Criticism: 
  The argument is not that all dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients, but specifically that dried parsley is inferior to fresh parsley.
  Therefore, principle E may be too broad and not specific enough to justify the argument.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 67 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Detective: Because the embezzler must have had specialized knowledge and access to internal financial records, we can presume that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary. But an accountant would probably not make the kind of mistakes in ledger entries that led to the discovery of the embezzlement. Thus it is likely that the embezzler is one of the actuaries.
Question: Each of the following weakens the detective's argument EXCEPT:
Choices:
  A: The actuaries' activities while working for XYZ Corporation were more closely scrutinized by supervisors than were the activities of the accountants.
  B: There is evidence of breaches in computer security at the time of the embezzlement that could have given persons outside XYZ Corporation access to internal financial records.
  C: XYZ Corporation employs eight accountants, whereas it has only two actuaries on its staff.
  D: An independent report released before the crime took place concluded that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement.
  E: Certain security measures at XYZ Corporation made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records than for the accountants.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The detective presumes that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary.
  The detective argues that the embezzler is likely one of the actuaries because an accountant would not make the kind of mistakes that led to the discovery of the embezzlement.
Thought:
  A: If the activities of the actuaries were more closely scrutinized than those of the accountants, it would be less likely that one of the actuaries could have embezzled the money.
  B: If persons outside XYZ Corporation had access to the internal financial records, it is possible that the embezzlement was committed by someone who was not an accountant or an actuary.
  C: If there are more accountants than actuaries, it is less likely that the embezzler is one of the actuaries.
  D: If an independent report concluded that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement before the crime took place, it is possible that the embezzlement was committed by someone who was not an accountant or an actuary.
  E: If security measures made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records than for the accountants, it is less likely that one of the actuaries could have embezzled the money.
  None of these choices directly weaken the detective's argument.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 68 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: One should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
Question: The principle stated above, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?
Choices:
  A: I should not have played that practical joke on you yesterday. Even if it was not contemptuous, I should have realized that it would bring significant harm to someone.
  B: I have no reason to think that the practical joke I want to play would harm anyone. So, since the joke would show no contempt for the person the joke is played on, it would not be wrong for me to play it.
  C: Because of the circumstances, it would be wrong for me to play the practical joke I had intended to play on you. Even though it would not show contempt for anyone, it could easily bring you significant harm.
  D: It would have been wrong for me to play the practical joke that I had intended to play on you. Even though I did not have reason to think that it would significantly harm anyone, I did think that it would show contempt for someone.
  E: Someone was harmed as a result of my practical joke. Thus, even though it did not show contempt for the person I played the joke on, I should not have played it.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The principle stated above is that one should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
Thought:
  A: The argument agrees with the principle stated above, as the person acknowledges that the joke could have brought significant harm to someone.
  B: The argument does not agree with the principle stated above, as it only considers whether the joke would show contempt for the person.
  C: The argument agrees with the principle stated above, as the person acknowledges that the joke could bring significant harm to someone.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 69 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A film makes a profit if the number of people who see it is sufficient to generate revenues from ticket sales greater than the amount spent to make it. Hence, the primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film. However, it is not the primary goal of television executives to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives?
Choices:
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
Thought: 
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film because ticket sales generate revenue.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows because the revenue model is different.
  Option A is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Option B is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Option C is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Option D is relevant because television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  Option E is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Therefore, the answer is D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
Criticism: 
  The answer is logically sound. 
  It is possible that other factors could also contribute to the difference in goals between movie executives and television executives.
Action: Answer("D")

Thought: 
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film because the more people who see it, the more revenue they can generate from ticket sales.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows because they make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  Choice D most helps to explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives because it explains that television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show. Therefore, television executives are more concerned with attracting viewers who have a higher purchasing power, rather than just maximizing the number of viewers.
  Therefore, the answer is D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
Criticism: 
  Choice C could also be a possible answer because if the average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television, then movie executives would have to maximize the number of people who see a film to generate enough revenue to cover the high production costs. However, choice D is still a better answer because it directly explains the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 70 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Curator: Our museum displays only twentieth-century works, which are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection. Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store. The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Question: If the curator's statements are true, which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Every print in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection.
  B: Every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work.
  C: There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector.
  D: Hopper's Nighthawks is both a twentieth-century work and a work on loan to the museum from a private collector.
  E: Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
- The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
- The works are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
- Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
- The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.

Thought:
- Every print in the museum store is either a print of a work on loan from a private collector or a print of a work in the museum's permanent collection.
- Every print in the museum store is a print of a twentieth-century work.
- Not every work displayed in the museum is in the museum's permanent collection.
- Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection, but it is a twentieth-century work.
- There is no information to suggest that Hopper's Nighthawks is on loan to the museum from a private collector.
- There is no information to suggest that every work displayed in the museum is available as a print in the museum store.

Evaluation:
- Choice A is incorrect because the museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection.
- Choice B is correct because the museum displays only twentieth-century works, and prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
- Choice C is incorrect because there is no information to suggest that every work displayed in the museum is available as a print in the museum store.
- Choice D is incorrect because there is no information to suggest that Hopper's Nighthawks is on loan to the museum from a private collector.
- Choice E is irrelevant because the question is not about whether Hopper's Nighthawks is displayed in the museum.

Action: Answer("B")

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 71 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it. However, in some cases a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it. For example, a person should never be blamed for unwittingly bringing about misfortune if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Question: The principles above, if valid, most help to justify the reasoning in which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to Riley that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. So, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. So, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  D: When Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, he did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. So, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  E: Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Thus, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The principles state that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street without realizing that it could lead to a traffic accident. 
  B: Oblicek suggested that her brother take out a loan to expand his business without realizing that it could cause the business to go bankrupt.
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests without reason to think it would make them ill, but was concerned that it might.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which any reasonable person could have foreseen would start a fire.
Thought: 
  A: Riley did not realize that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident, so he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, so she should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Therefore, he should not be blamed for it.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure, so he should not be blamed for it.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which any reasonable person could have foreseen would start a fire. Therefore, she should be blamed for it.
  The principles help to justify the reasoning in A, B, C, and D, but not in E.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The passage explains that a person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it, but a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if they could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Thought: 
  Option A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street, which could lead to a traffic accident. Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to him. Therefore, he should not be blamed for it.
  Option B: Oblicek suggested to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business, which was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt. She had no idea that this would happen, nor could she have reasonably foreseen it. Therefore, she should not be blamed for it.
  Option C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests, which made them ill. He had no reason to think that it would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Therefore, he should be blamed for it.
  Option D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, which caused the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. He did not know that it would cause this. Therefore, he is to blame for it.
  Option E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which started a fire. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that this would start a fire. Therefore, she is to blame for it.
  Option A and B are consistent with the principles outlined in the passage, while options C, D, and E are not.
  Option A and B both involve situations where the person did not realize that their actions could lead to misfortune and could not have reasonably foreseen it. Therefore, they should not be blamed for it.
  Option A and B are both valid justifications for the principles outlined in the passage.
Action: Answer("B")

  The passage states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Thought: 
  Option A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street without realizing it could lead to a traffic accident. If a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Option B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. If the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Option C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it. This contradicts the principle stated in the passage.
  Option D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. If no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Option E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm without realizing it could start a fire. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Kapp is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there. This contradicts the principle stated in the passage.
Conclusion: 
  Options A, B, and D align with the principle stated in the passage, while options C and E contradict it. Option A and B both describe situations where a person unwittingly brings about misfortune and could not reasonably have foreseen it, so they both help to justify the reasoning in the passage.

  D: The example is valid since Dr. Fitzpatrick did not know that the wrong medicine would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure.

  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting a loan to her brother would cause his business to go bankrupt, and she could not have reasonably foreseen this. Therefore, she should not be blamed for her brother's business going bankrupt.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, and he was concerned that it might. Therefore, he should not be blamed for his guests getting sick.

Response 8:
Knowledge: 
  The principles state that a person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it, but a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if they could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street and did not realize it could lead to a traffic accident. 
  B: Oblicek suggested her brother to take out a loan to expand his business and had no idea it would cause the business to go bankrupt. 
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests and did not think it would make them ill. 
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. 
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm and did not realize it could start a fire.
Thought: 
  Option A: Riley did not realize that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. Therefore, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  Option B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. Therefore, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  Option C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  Option D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. So, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  Option E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm and did not realize it could start a fire. However, any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, Kapp is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm.
  Options A and B fit the principles stated in the context. Option C does not fit the principles because Gougon should have reasonably foreseen that serving the hollandaise sauce could make his guests ill. Option D does not fit the principles because Dr. Fitzpatrick knowingly gave the patient the wrong medicine. Option E does not fit the principles because any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. 
  Therefore, the answer is either A or B. 
Criticism: 
  The principles stated in the context are valid and the answer choices are clear. 
Action: Answer("B")
Response 9:
Knowledge: 
  The principle mentioned in the context is that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street and did not realize that it could lead to a traffic accident. 
  B: Oblicek suggested to her brother to take out a loan to expand his business, but had no idea that it could cause the business to go bankrupt.
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests and did not think it would make them ill.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which started a fire.
Thought: 
  According to the principle mentioned in the context, a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  In option A, Riley did not realize that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. If a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  In option B, Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. If the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  In option C, Gougon did not think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill. However, he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  In option D, Dr. Fitzpatrick did not know that giving the wrong medicine to his patient would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. If no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  In option E, any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Thus, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
  Therefore, options A and B are consistent with the principle mentioned in the context, while options C, D, and E are not.
Action: Answer("B")
Votes: A, B, B, B, B, B, B, A, B, B

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 72 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: People who have specialized knowledge about a scientific or technical issue are systematically excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant. Thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
Choices:
  A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B: The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C: Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
  D: Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
  E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The argument is that people with specialized knowledge are excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant, and thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
  A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B: The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C: Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
  D: Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
  E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Thought: 
  The argument is that people with specialized knowledge are excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant, and thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
  A weakens the argument by stating that the more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B does not weaken the argument, as it states that the more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C is irrelevant to the argument, as it talks about appointing an impartial arbitrator, not about trial by jury.
  D is also irrelevant to the argument, as it talks about how experts give testimony, not about the fairness of trial by jury.
  E is also irrelevant to the argument, as it talks about the cost of expert witnesses, not about the fairness of trial by jury.
  Therefore, A is the best answer as it weakens the argument.
Action: Answer("A")

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 73 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Richard: Because it fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art—that it represent—abstract art will eventually be seen as an aberration. Jung-Su: Although artists, like musicians, may reject literal representation, makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected. Thus, whatever others might come to say, abstract art is part of the artistic mainstream.
Question: Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether
Choices:
  A: makers of abstract art reject literal representation
  B: the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent
  C: musicians may reject literal representation
  D: abstract art will be seen as an aberration
  E: abstract art is representational
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Richard believes that abstract art fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art, which is to represent.
  Jung-Su believes that makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected.
Thought:
  Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent.
  Richard believes that it is, while Jung-Su believes that makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects.
  Therefore, the answer is B: the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent.
Action: Answer("B")

  B: Richard believes that the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent.
  C: Jung-Su mentions that musicians may reject literal representation, but this is not the main point of disagreement.
  D: Richard believes that abstract art will eventually be seen as an aberration.
  E: Jung-Su believes that abstract art is representational, but in a different way than realistic art.

  Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether abstract art meets the fundamental requirement of art.
  Richard believes that art must represent something, while Jung-Su believes that abstract art represents the purely formal features of objects.
  Therefore, they disagree over whether abstract art is representational.
  The answer is E: abstract art is representational.

Context: Geologist: The dominant view that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals deep in the earth's crust has been challenged by scientists who hold that it formed, not from living material, but from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth. But their theory is refuted by the presence in petroleum of biomarkers, molecules indicating the past or present existence of a living organism.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the geologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Fossils have been discovered that are devoid of biomarkers.
  B: Living organisms only emerged long after the earth's formation.
  C: It would take many millions of years for organisms to become petroleum.
  D: Certain strains of bacteria thrive deep inside the earth's crust.
  E: Some carbon deposits were formed from the fossilized remains of plants.

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 75 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: City leader: If our city adopts the new tourism plan, the amount of money that tourists spend here annually will increase by at least $2 billion, creating as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would. It would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant here, but adopting the tourism plan would cost less.
Question: The city leader's statements, if true, provide the most support for which one of the following
Choices:
  A: The city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available.
  B: In general, it is reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city.
  C: The city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan.
  D: It would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
  E: The only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will increase the amount of money that tourists spend in the city by at least $2 billion annually.
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will create as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would.
  The city leader believes that it would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city.
Thought: 
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will increase the amount of money that tourists spend in the city by at least $2 billion annually.
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will create as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would.
  The city leader believes that it would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city.
  The city leader believes that adopting the tourism plan would cost less than convincing an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city.
  Therefore, the city leader's statements provide the most support for the conclusion that it would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
  The answer is D: It would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
Criticism: 
  There is no support for the conclusion that the city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available (choice A).
  The city leader's statements do not provide support for the general proposition that it is reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city (choice B).
  There is no evidence that the city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan (choice C).
  There is no support for the conclusion that the only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism (choice E).

### Temperature: 3.0 | Problem 76 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Student: If a person has an immunity to infection by a microorganism, then that microorganism does not cause them to develop harmful symptoms. Since many people are exposed to staphylococcus without developing any harmful symptoms, it follows that they have an immunity to infection by this microorganism.
Question: The student's argument is most similar in its flawed pattern of reasoning to which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Everything morally right is just, but some actions that best serve the interests of everyone are not just. Thus, some morally right actions do not serve the interests of everyone.
  B: Advertisers try to persuade people that certain claims are true. Since writers of fiction are not advertisers, they probably never try to persuade people that certain claims are true.
  C: Isabel said that she would take the medication. Obviously, though, she did not do so, because medication either cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, and Isabel is still quite ill.
  D: When business owners are subjected to excessive taxation, they become less willing to expand their businesses. The recent decline in business expansions thus shows that their taxes are too high.
  E: Studies show that doctors tend to wash their hands less often than any other health care professionals. This shows that the procedure cannot be of much value in preventing disease.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The student argues that if a person does not develop harmful symptoms after being exposed to a microorganism, then they must have an immunity to that microorganism.
  The argument is flawed because not developing symptoms does not necessarily mean that a person has immunity to the microorganism.
  A: This argument is about the relationship between morality and the interests of everyone. It is not similar to the student's argument.
  B: This argument is about whether writers of fiction try to persuade people that certain claims are true. It is not similar to the student's argument.
  C: This argument is about whether Isabel took medication or not. It is not similar to the student's argument.
  D: This argument is about the relationship between excessive taxation and business expansion. It is not similar to the student's argument.
  E: This argument is about the value of hand-washing in preventing disease. It is not similar to the student's argument.
Thought: 
  The student's argument is flawed because not developing symptoms does not necessarily mean that a person has immunity to the microorganism.
  The argument assumes that exposure to the microorganism is the only factor that determines whether a person develops harmful symptoms.
  Therefore, the student's argument is most similar in its flawed pattern of reasoning to C: Isabel said that she would take the medication. Obviously, though, she did not do so, because medication either cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, and Isabel is still quite ill.
Criticism: 
  You are correct that the student's argument is flawed because not developing symptoms does not necessarily mean that a person has immunity to the microorganism.
  However, the argument does not assume that exposure to the microorganism is the only factor that determines whether a person develops harmful symptoms.
  Therefore, the answer may not be C.
Action: Answer("C")
